rows.text_1_facilitator:
I'M HUNGRY! HE HIT ME! I'M BORED!
Sound familiar? 

Every family faces challenges. Learning how to solve problems together with your child can help you when you have conflict in your home. 

It also teaches your children how to solve problems on their own. This will set them up for success throughout their life. What a gift!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
I'M HUNGRY! HE HIT ME! I'M BORED!
Sound familiar? 

Every family faces challenges. Learning how to solve problems together with your child can help you when you have conflict in your home. 

It also teaches your children how to solve problems on their own. This will set them up for success throughout their life. What a gift!

media_title.eng: Tap play to hear how solving problems with your children can you and your family

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, everyone.

As parents, it can feel like we have to solve a million problems for our children every day: Where is my toy car? I am not going to school! Why can’t you buy me new shoes now?

By involving our children in solving problems, they learn to find solutions more and more independently. 

Life has its challenges. If you help your child solve small problems today, you give them the skills to deal with any bigger challenges later in life.

rows.media_title: Tap play to hear how solving problems with your children can you and your family
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

As parents, it can feel like we have to solve a million problems for our children every day: Where is my toy car? I am not going to school! Why can’t you buy me new shoes now?

By involving our children in solving problems, they learn to find solutions more and more independently. 

Life has its challenges. If you help your child solve small problems today, you give them the skills to deal with any bigger challenges later in life.

text_2.eng:
**In the next story, @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name and @data.characters.f2_son_8.name use four steps to solve a problem:**

1) 💡 KNOW IT: Talk to your child about what the problem is
2) 🔧 SOLVE IT: Think of possible solutions together
3) 🎯 TRY IT: Choose one solution to try
4) 💭 REFLECT: See if it worked. If not, try another solution

4) 💭 REFLECT: See if it worked. If not, try another solution

character_1_text.eng: Come on, @data.characters.f2_son_8.name, it's time to get ready for bed.

character_2_text.eng: But I still have so much homework to do!

character_3_text.eng: Hmm, this is the third night in a row that you haven’t gone to bed on time because of homework.

rows.character_1_text: Come on, @data.characters.f2_son_8.name, it's time to get ready for bed.
rows.character_2_text: But I still have so much homework to do!
rows.character_3_text: Hmm, this is the third night in a row that you haven’t gone to bed on time because of homework.

character_1_text.eng: How can we make sure you get all your work done and still get to bed on time so that you get enough sleep?

character_3_text.eng: Shall we make a rule that you start your homework half an hour after you get home from school? That way, you can finish it and have some time to eat and relax before bed, too!

character_1_text.eng: Look, @data.characters.f2_grandfather.role_name, I'm ready for bed earlier tonight!

character_2_text.eng: Well done, @data.characters.f2_son_8.name. I’m proud that we figured that problem out together. Now you can be well-rested for tomorrow, and your homework is done!

rows.text_1_facilitator:
When a problem comes up, take a deep breath before you respond. 

Then help your child work on the problem with you using these four steps.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
When a problem comes up, take a deep breath before you respond. 

Then help your child work on the problem with you using these four steps.

section_1_text.eng:
Put the problem into words.

Talk to your child about what the problem is.

section_1_extra_text.eng: _"I can hear you arguing because you don’t want to watch the same television programme. I know I said you both could watch TV after you’ve helped clean up after dinner, but we only have one television. How can we solve this problem?"_

section_2_text.eng:
Together, think of possible solutions to this problem.
What could you or your child do differently in this situation in the future?

section_2_extra_text.eng: _"One option is for us not to turn the television on at all. You can also take turns choosing a programme or select one you both want to watch. What do you both think?"_

section_3_text.eng:
Choose one solution together.

Try it next time you are in a similar situation, and praise your child for trying!

section_3_extra_text.eng:
_"Okay boys, do you remember what we said last night about the TV? Who can remember the solution we came up with?"
"That's right – well done for remembering! Let's try to pick a programme that you both want to watch – I can even come watch with you!"_

section_4_text.eng: After you’ve tried it, decide with your child whether or not your solution worked.

section_4_extra_text.eng: After the programme ends… _“Well that was an exciting game! I never knew I liked watching soccer so much, so thank you for introducing me to something new! I think we all had fun watching that together.”_

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s think of some common problems we could solve with our children.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s think of some common problems we could solve with our children.

quiz_1_question.eng: Do you experience any of these problems at home with your children?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Talk with your child and use the steps of problem-solving together to come up with solutions that you can try out.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Your home activity is to identify a problem your child may have and practise the four steps of problem-solving together: Know It, Solve It, Try It, Reflect. 

Knowing how to solve problems is something they can use for the rest of their lives!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Your home activity is to identify a problem your child may have and practise the four steps of problem-solving together: Know It, Solve It, Try It, Reflect. 

Knowing how to solve problems is something they can use for the rest of their lives!

media_title.eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_female_5.name and her daughter use the four steps of problem solving

media_transcript.eng:
I did not have a good relationship with my daughter. I was always shouting at her, and she was refusing to go to school. 

Only when I started spending One-on-One Time with her, I realised that she did not want to go to school because she was being bullied at school. We sat down and used the four steps of problem solving. We identified the problem, and figured out solutions together: “What can I do as a parent so you can attend school and feel safe?”

We agreed I would go talk to the teacher to find a way forward. We really found the solutions together, and we are closer now.

quiz_1_question.eng: Can you try to solve a problem with your child this week?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! Remember to praise them for their effort, and praise yourself, too! Well done!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's great! Remember to praise them for their effort, and praise yourself, too! Well done!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. Try to work on a simple problem with your child, before you tackle a big one together.

I did not have a good relationship with my daughter. I was always shouting at her, and she was refusing to go to school. 

Only when I started spending One-on-One Time with her, I realised that she did not want to go to school because she was being bullied at school. We sat down and used the four steps of problem solving. We identified the problem, and figured out solutions together: “What can I do as a parent so you can attend school and feel safe?”

We agreed I would go talk to the teacher to find a way forward. We really found the solutions together, and we are closer now.
